article:
'Redistributive change' is a legal theory of economic justice in the context of
U.S. law that promotes the recognition of poverty as a classification, like
race, ethnicity, gender, and religion, that should likewise draw extra scrutiny
from the courts in matters pertaining to civil rights. {{cite
web |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2203237/ |title=He's Not Robin Hood: What Obama
really meant by "redistributive change." |first=Emily |last=Bazelon
|publisher=Slate |date=2008-10-28}}

The theory was discussed in academia in the wake of [[Goldberg v. Kelly]], a
1970 U.S. Supreme Court case, which decided that due process, such as a notice
and a fair hearing, were required when dealing with the deprivation of a
government benefit (such as a medical license) or an entitlement (such as
welfare payments). However, attempts to promote
redistributive change through the courts gained no traction, and the result of
Goldberg v. Kelly was thus limited in scope.

One of the goals, in light of [[Brown v. Board of Education]], was to promote
equality in school funding, but this was specifically rejected by the Supreme
Court in [[San Antonio School District v. Rodriguez]] (1973) which ruled there
was no inherent right to education in the United States. {{cite web
|url=http://www.wbez.org/audio_library/od_rajan01.asp#010118 |title=The Court
and Civil Rights |first=Gretchen |last=Helfrich |coauthors=Susan Bandes, Dennis
Hutchinson, and Barack Obama |publisher=Chicago Public Radio |date=2001-01-18
|quote=A classic example would be something like public education, where after
Brown v. Board, a major issue ends up being redistribution -- how do we get more
money into the schools, and how do we actually create equal schools and equal
educational opportunity? Well, the court in a case called San Antonio v.
Rodriguez in the early '70s basically slaps those kinds of claims down, and
says, 'You know what, we as a court have no power to examine issues of
redistribution and wealth inequalities. With respect to schools, that's not a
race issue, that's a wealth issue and something we can't get into.'}}

A discussion among two law professors and Illinois State Senator and law
lecturer Barack Obama on the topic of civil rights aired on Chicago Public
Radio's Odyssey program in 2001. {{cite web
|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/29/us/politics/29campaign.html?em
|title=Candidates Battle for Pennsylvania |first=Michael |last=Cooper
|coauthors=Jack Healy |publisher=The New York Times |date=2008-10-28}}
Obama declared in the discussion that redistributive change needs to come
through legislation, not the courts, and lamented that the
civil rights movement failed to pursue political means to bring such a change
about. {{cite web |url=http://www.salon.com/opinion/walsh/election_2008/200-
8/10/28/obama_civil_rights/index.html?source=newsletter |title=What Obama really
said in 2001 |first=Joan |last=Walsh |publisher=Salon |date=2008-10-28}}
As a result of Obama's candidacy in the 2008 U.S. Presidential election, the
matter became a campaign issue during the final week of the election, {{cite
web |url=http://www.boston.com/news/politics/politicalintelligence/2008/10/mcca-
in_slams_ob_3.html |title=McCain slams Obama on 'redistribution of wealth'
|first=Foon |last=Rhee |publisher=The Boston Globe |date=2007-10-
27}} {{cite web |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/the-
trail/2008/10/28/palin_takes_issue_liberally_wi.html |title=Palin Takes Issue,
Liberally, With '01 Obama Remarks |first=Juliet |last=Eilperin |coauthors=Alice
Crites |publisher=Washington Post |date=2008-10-28}} fueling a charge made
by his opponent, U.S. Senator John McCain, that Obama was a closet
socialist. {{cite web |url=http://features.csmonitor.com/politics/2008/10/30/mccain-makes-his-
closing-arguments/ |title=McCain makes his closing arguments: Behind in the
polls and in key swing states, he throws everything he can at Obama |first=Linda
|last=Feldmann |publisher=Christian Science Monitor |date=2008-10-30}}
